text: Hello everyone. I'm Anant, a junior applying for GSoC this term under <https://github.com/aced-differentiate/|Alchemy.jl> - an ecosystem for machine learning on atomic systems. The work I propose aims to introduce, and improve upon existing methods for property prediction of crystalline materials, in Julia. Considering the domain-relevance, I thought I'd drop a <https://docs.google.com/document/d/12Hsez0D2XUamYDYBzn1Ij2s-cFam41GsuLo_OxTpKec/edit|link to my proposal> here too, and hopefully get some valuable feedback from anyone here who would have the time to go through it. Eager too see what you all think of it. Thanks in advance!

text:
<@U01QRM4E8HL> - I have some comments on this. Overall I think the project is cool :slightly_smiling_face: and worth doing for a number of reasons.

I don't know how rigorous GSoC proposals have to be, my guess is not very rigorous, but here's some stuff I'd personally like to see. Talk with your mentor if these make sense or if they are excessive :slightly_smiling_face:.

1. In the testing section add, how you plan on testing the results. Are there some key calculations you wish to compare against the literature impl? How about a publicly available dataset or 2 for getting the whole picture.
2. Offer the other title of Alchemy.jl - just for posterity. If the repo/project hasn't changed names yet there is some risk there. Include both names just incase :slightly_smiling_face:.
3. This sentance reads like you're putting yourself down "and although I'm relatively fresh with Julia". Just focus on your experience in the area and how you're passionate about the language.
4. Give that super high level description of what this code serves to do. Like in laypersons terms - it's likely your judges will be software engineers in a hurry to review these things. I can suss out what this model does, but someone without that background might not be able too without some training wheels.
5. maybe add some other stuff about how this could further the ecosystem. You mention it a bit, but are there any other composible things that will fall out of the project that other's can use? Is one of those potentially important? Maybe some new adjoints or something?
6. maybe describe how other packages (related to this) show some improvement when translated to Julia. Whether it's performance, ease of use, developer speed, etc. That's a big chunk of your impact here. Try and sell how that is important?
Anyways that's me from the peanut gallery not understanding GSoC at all. Again it sounds like a great project to learn some things and contribute to the ecosystem. I just don't know how serious GSoC is.
